titlestmt.titleproper: Consumer Reports. Edward M. Brecher papers
Guide to the Consumer Reports. Edward M. Brecher papers, 1928-1967 and undated RL.11803
titlestmt.author: Richard Collier

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-18 21:50:12 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Consumer Reports. Edward M. Brecher papers
did.abstract: Consumer Reports is a product testing and consumer advocacy nonprofit organization based in Yonkers, N.Y., founded in 1936. Edward M. Brecher was a journalist and free-lance science writer who served as Associate Editor of Consumer Reports publications in the 1940s-1950s. The Edward M. Brecher papers include clippings, correspondence, drafts of articles, research notes and other printed materials relating to some of Brecher's writing projects including articles co-written with Ruth Brecher. Topics represented include consumer education and protection, nursing home care, health and legal aspects of smoking, and urban transportation systems. Organizations represented include the American Cancer Society, Department of Health Education and Welfare, Federal Trade Commission, J. Walter Thompson, Liggett & Myers, and the U.S. Supreme Court. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: Consumer and the Supreme Court; Nursing Homes; Smoking; Smoking and the Consumer Interest; Urban Transportation.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Consumer Reports is a product testing and consumer advocacy nonprofit organization based in Yonkers, N.Y., founded in 1936. Edward M. Brecher was a journalist and free-lance science writer who served as Associate Editor of Consumer Reports publications in the 1940s-1950s.

Edward M. Brecher was born in 1912 in Minnesota. He graduated with degrees from Swarthmore (BA, 1932) and the University of Minnesota (MS, 1934). Brecher served as Associate Editor of Consumer Reports 1947-1951. His spouse, Ruth Ernestine Cook Brecher, frequently served as research partner and co-author. Brecher published two books: Consumer Union Report on Licit and Illicit Drugs (1972) and Love, Sex and Aging (1984). He died in 1989.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Consumer Reports. Edward M. Brecher papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Consumer Reports. Edward M. Brecher papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2019-0130

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in the following Hartman Center collections:
Lois Stifel collection of tobacco ephemera;
Richard Pollay Tobacco industry promotion collection

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Consumer Reports is a product testing and consumer advocacy nonprofit organization based in Yonkers, N.Y., founded in 1936. Edward M. Brecher was a journalist and free-lance science writer who served as Associate Editor of Consumer Reports publications in the 1940s-1950s. The Edward M. Brecher papers include clippings, correspondence, drafts of articles, research notes and other printed materials relating to some of Brecher's writing projects including articles co-written with Ruth Brecher. Topics represented include consumer education and protection, nursing home care, health and legal aspects of smoking, and urban transportation systems. Organizations represented include the American Cancer Society, Department of Health Education and Welfare, Federal Trade Commission, J. Walter Thompson, Liggett & Myers, and the U.S. Supreme Court.
